rows: Belief that one is being harassed, conspired against, or targeted (most common type)
Belief that gestures, comments, environmental cues are directed at oneself
Belief of having exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame
Belief that another person is in love with the individual
Belief that a major catastrophe will occur or that one does not exist
Belief that thoughts are being placed in, removed from, or broadcast from one's mind
Belief that one's body or actions are being controlled by an outside force
options: Referential
Grandiose
Erotomanic
Persecutory
questions.explanation: Erotomanic delusions involve the belief that another person, often of higher status, is in love with the individual. This is distinct from grandiose delusions (exceptional abilities/fame), referential delusions (environmental cues directed at oneself), and persecutory delusions (being targeted or harassed).

rows: Bullying, initiating fights, using weapons, physical cruelty to people or animals, forcing sexual activity
Deliberately setting fires, deliberately destroying property
Breaking into someone's house/car, lying to obtain goods, shoplifting
questions.correct_value: Staying out late (before age 13), running away, truancy (before age 13)
options: Breaking into someone's house/car, lying to obtain goods, shoplifting
Staying out late (before age 13), running away, truancy (before age 13)
Deliberately setting fires, deliberately destroying property
Bullying, initiating fights, using weapons, physical cruelty to people or animals, forcing sexual activity
questions.explanation: The 'Serious violations of rules' category in Conduct Disorder specifically includes staying out late (before age 13), running away from home overnight, and truancy (before age 13). The age qualifier of 'before age 13' is a key diagnostic detail that distinguishes these behaviors as symptoms of Conduct Disorder rather than typical adolescent rule-breaking.

rows: May achieve academic skills ~6th grade level; needs support with complex daily living tasks
Limited language and self-care; requires daily supervision
Dependent on others for all aspects of care; very limited communication
questions.correct_value: Academic skills ~2nd grade level; needs support for daily activities
options: Limited language and self-care; requires daily supervision
Academic skills ~2nd grade level; needs support for daily activities
May achieve academic skills ~6th grade level; needs support with complex daily living tasks
Dependent on others for all aspects of care; very limited communication
questions.explanation: Moderate Intellectual Disability (IQ approximately 35-40 to 50-55) is characterized by academic skill attainment around the 2nd grade level with the need for support in daily activities. This is commonly confused with Mild ID (~6th grade level) or Severe ID (limited language and self-care), making it a highly testable distinction on the EPPP.

rows: Rising from bed and walking; blank stare, difficult to awaken, amnesia for episode
Abrupt awakening with panicked scream, intense fear, autonomic arousal, amnesia
Extended, dysphoric, well-remembered dreams; full alertness on awakening
questions.correct_value: Acting out dreams due to loss of normal REM atonia; associated with neurodegenerative disease
options: Abrupt awakening with panicked scream, intense fear, autonomic arousal, amnesia
Acting out dreams due to loss of normal REM atonia; associated with neurodegenerative disease
Extended, dysphoric, well-remembered dreams; full alertness on awakening
Rising from bed and walking; blank stare, difficult to awaken, amnesia for episode
questions.explanation: REM sleep behavior disorder is characterized by the loss of normal REM atonia (muscle paralysis during REM sleep), which causes individuals to physically act out their dreams. It is notably associated with neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia. This distinguishes it from nightmare disorder, which also occurs during REM sleep but involves only disturbing dreams without motor activity.

rows: Observing unsuspecting persons undressing/in sexual activity
Must be 18+ years old; prevalence up to 12% in males
May involve desire to surprise, shock, or impress
Touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person
Typically occurs in crowded public settings
Being humiliated, beaten, or otherwise made to suffer
Specify if with asphyxiophilia (arousal by oxygen deprivation)
Physical or psychological suffering of another person
Must involve nonconsenting partner or cause distress
Sexual activity with prepubescent children (generally 13 or younger)
Nonliving objects or highly specific nongenital body parts
Does not include garments used for cross-dressing
Applies to heterosexual males; specify with fetishism or autogynephilia
questions.correct_value: Individual must be at least 16 and at least 5 years older than the child; specify exclusive/nonexclusive type
options: Must be 18+ years old; specify exclusive/nonexclusive type based on gender preference
Individual must be at least 16 and at least 5 years older than the child; specify exclusive/nonexclusive type
Individual must be at least 18 and at least 3 years older than the child; specify attraction type
Must involve nonconsenting partner or cause distress; specify exclusive/nonexclusive type
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Pedophilic Disorder specify that the individual must be at least 16 years old and at least 5 years older than the child (who is generally age 13 or younger). Clinicians must also specify whether the attraction is exclusive (attracted only to children) or nonexclusive type. These specific age thresholds (16 and 5-year difference) are commonly tested and frequently confused with other age cutoffs.

rows: Fear of causing harm to self/others
options: Mental rituals, checking
Excessive washing, cleaning
Checking locks, stoves, appliances
Arranging, ordering, counting
questions.explanation: The Harm dimension of OCD involves obsessions about causing harm to self or others, and the associated compulsions specifically involve checking behaviors targeted at potential sources of danger (e.g., locks, stoves, appliances). This is distinct from the general 'checking' listed under Forbidden Thoughts, which pairs with mental rituals in response to intrusive aggressive, sexual, or religious thoughts.

rows: Not considering change; unaware of or minimizes the problem
Raise awareness; express concern without confrontation
Aware of problem; ambivalent about change; weighing pros/cons
Intending to take action; making plans; may have taken small steps
Help develop a concrete plan; identify resources
Actively modifying behavior; engaging in treatment
Relapse prevention; identify triggers; build coping skills
questions.correct_value: Explore ambivalence; tip the decisional balance
options: Raise awareness; express concern without confrontation
Explore ambivalence; tip the decisional balance
Help develop a concrete plan; identify resources
Relapse prevention; identify triggers; build coping skills
questions.explanation: In the Contemplation stage, the individual is aware of the problem but is ambivalent about change and actively weighing pros and cons. The appropriate clinical approach is to explore that ambivalence and help tip the decisional balance toward change. This is distinct from Precontemplation (where the goal is raising awareness) and Preparation (where the goal is developing a concrete action plan).

rows: Similar to alcohol; anxiety, tremor, seizures
Irritability, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite
options: Tremor, seizures, hallucinations, autonomic instability
Flu-like symptoms, pupil dilation, piloerection
Irritability, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite
"Crash": depression, fatigue, hypersomnia, increased appetite
questions.explanation: Opioid withdrawal is characterized by flu-like symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle aches), pupil dilation (mydriasis), and piloerection (goosebumps). These features are distinct from the autonomic instability and seizures seen in alcohol/benzodiazepine withdrawal, and from the depressive 'crash' associated with stimulant withdrawal. Piloerection is a hallmark sign that is highly specific to opioid withdrawal and frequently tested on the EPPP.

rows: PDE-5 inhibitors (sildenafil/Viagra); CBT; couples therapy; sensate focus
CBT; mindfulness-based therapies; hormonal therapy (in some cases); addressing relationship factors
Directed masturbation training; sensate focus; CBT; bibliotherapy
Pelvic floor physical therapy; graduated vaginal dilators; CBT; pain management
questions.correct_value: Squeeze technique and stop-start technique (Masters & Johnson/Semans); SSRIs (off-label); topical anesthetics
options: Directed masturbation training; sensate focus; CBT; bibliotherapy
Squeeze technique and stop-start technique (Masters & Johnson/Semans); SSRIs (off-label); topical anesthetics
PDE-5 inhibitors (sildenafil/Viagra); CBT; couples therapy; sensate focus
Pelvic floor physical therapy; graduated vaginal dilators; CBT; pain management
questions.explanation: Premature ejaculation is primarily treated with behavioral techniques developed by Masters & Johnson (squeeze technique) and Semans (stop-start technique), along with off-label use of SSRIs (which delay ejaculation as a side effect) and topical anesthetics to reduce penile sensitivity. These are distinct from treatments for other sexual dysfunctions and are highly testable because of the specific association of the squeeze/stop-start techniques with their originators.

options: Married
Developing country
Good premorbid functioning
Prominent mood symptoms
questions.explanation: WHO research has found that individuals with schizophrenia in developing countries tend to have a better prognosis than those in developed countries, a counterintuitive finding often tested on the EPPP. This is attributed to factors such as greater family involvement and social support in developing nations.

rows: Difficulty sustaining attention, does not follow through, loses things, easily distracted, forgetful
Fidgets, leaves seat, runs/climbs inappropriately, talks excessively, interrupts, difficulty waiting
options: Difficulty sustaining attention, does not follow through, loses things, easily distracted, forgetful
Most commonly diagnosed presentation
Requires onset of symptoms before age 7
Fidgets, leaves seat, runs/climbs inappropriately, talks excessively, interrupts, difficulty waiting
questions.explanation: The Combined presentation of ADHD, which meets criteria for both inattentive and hyperactive-impulsive symptom clusters, is the most commonly diagnosed presentation. This is a frequently tested fact on the EPPP, as examinees may confuse which presentation is most prevalent.

rows: Feeling tense, restless, difficulty concentrating due to worry, fear of something awful
Profound anhedonia, worse in morning, early morning awakening, psychomotor changes, excessive guilt
Onset during pregnancy or within 4 weeks of delivery
Regular temporal relationship between episode onset and time of year
questions.correct_value: Mood reactivity, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, interpersonal rejection sensitivity, weight gain
options: Profound anhedonia, worse in morning, early morning awakening, psychomotor changes, excessive guilt
Mood reactivity, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, interpersonal rejection sensitivity, weight gain
Feeling tense, restless, difficulty concentrating due to worry, fear of something awful
Delusions or hallucinations (mood-congruent or mood-incongruent)
questions.explanation: The 'With atypical features' specifier is characterized by mood reactivity (mood brightens in response to positive events), hypersomnia, leaden paralysis (heavy feeling in arms/legs), interpersonal rejection sensitivity, and significant weight gain. This is frequently tested on the EPPP because it is easily confused with melancholic features, which presents with nearly opposite symptoms (e.g., anhedonia instead of mood reactivity, early morning awakening instead of hypersomnia, weight loss instead of weight gain).

rows: Parental antisocial behavior or substance use
options: Elevated cortisol reactivity (autonomic hyperarousal)
Low resting heart rate (autonomic underarousal)
Callous-unemotional traits
Reduced prefrontal cortex activity
questions.explanation: Research consistently identifies low resting heart rate, reflecting autonomic underarousal, as one of the best-replicated biological risk factors for antisocial and conduct-disordered behavior. This is often confused with hyperarousal, but it is specifically underarousal (low resting heart rate) that is associated with sensation-seeking and reduced fear conditioning, contributing to conduct problems.

rows: Limited evidence; Moral Reconation Therapy in forensic settings; CBT components; medication for comorbid conditions
CBT (similar to social anxiety); graduated exposure; social skills training
Limited research; supportive therapy; low-dose antipsychotics for schizotypal PD
questions.correct_value: DBT (Linehan); Mentalization-Based Treatment (MBT; Bateman & Fonagy); Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP; Kernberg); Schema Therapy (Young)
options: Limited evidence; Moral Reconation Therapy in forensic settings; CBT components; medication for comorbid conditions
CBT (similar to social anxiety); graduated exposure; social skills training
DBT (Linehan); Mentalization-Based Treatment (MBT; Bateman & Fonagy); Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP; Kernberg); Schema Therapy (Young)
Limited research; supportive therapy; low-dose antipsychotics for schizotypal PD
questions.explanation: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) has the most extensively researched evidence-based treatments among the personality disorders, including DBT developed by Linehan, Mentalization-Based Treatment (MBT) by Bateman and Fonagy, Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP) by Kernberg, and Schema Therapy by Young. This is a highly testable fact on the EPPP because BPD is the most commonly tested personality disorder and candidates must know the specific treatments and their developers.
